conclusion: To determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum, analyze the acceleration-time graph.
Velocity is at maximum when acceleration changes from positive to negative or becomes zero after being positive.
Velocity increases when acceleration is positive and decreases when acceleration is negative.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
Since the object starts from rest, its velocity is increasing during t = 0 to t = 1 second.
From t = 1 to t = 3 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s² at t = 2 seconds, then to -2 m/s² at t = 3 seconds.
At t = 2 seconds, acceleration is 0 m/s², meaning velocity is neither increasing nor decreasing.
After t = 2 seconds, acceleration becomes negative, indicating velocity will start decreasing.
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, acceleration remains constant at -2 m/s².
Velocity continues to decrease during t = 3 to t = 4 seconds.
Velocity reaches its maximum at t = 2 seconds when acceleration changes from positive to zero and then becomes negative.
The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 seconds.
